Key Arguments: The legislation is seen as an insult to governance and is considered ethically and morally wrong.
The government is accused of historically overriding natural rights, leading to tragedies.
Censorship is believed to drive bad ideas underground and mislabel truths as untruths.
The government is perceived as incompetent and malicious, likely to misuse censorship powers.
There is skepticism about the government's ability to determine truth, citing scientific replication issues.
The government is accused of being a major source of misinformation and disinformation.
The submission argues for government humility and restitution rather than increased powers.
Notable Quotes: It is antithetical to our system of governance, impossible to do properly, ethically and morally wrong.
Censorship always drives bad ideas underground where they fester, and the inevitable mislabelling of truths as untruths only sows distrust and division.
There is no safe way to wield this power, and no way for government to actually rule on what is true, especially for novel scenarios.
A trustworthy government simply has no need to tighten its grip.
